awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Transition between Ductile and Brittle Fracture Modes in Sintering Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Sintering is a high-temperature process used to transform loosely bound powder aggregates into near net-shaped, dense objects with controlled amounts of porosity.  In many sintering applications, external constraints can prevent a powder aggregate from densifying in one or more directions. Under these constrained sintering conditions, internal stresses can develop in the sintering material, and in extreme cases, these stresses can grow so large that they tear the powder aggregate apart. This fracture process, referred to as sinter-cracking, degrades product quality, lowers yield, and proves highly undesirable in manufacturing processes. This award supports fundamental research to understand the sinter-cracking phenomenon. The goal of this research is to clarify why this cracking occurs, with a view toward identifying processing strategies for suppressing fracture during constrained sintering. By relating material properties, geometric factors, and process variables to the growth of sinter-cracks, this research will guide materials engineers towards processing and manufacturing parameters to prevent catastrophic sinter-cracking. This new scientific knowledge will have important applications in the powder processing industry, potentially benefiting a range of manufacturing sectors, particularly those making use of new 3D printing technologies, including the aerospace, automotive, and energy sectors.

This research project aims to understand the ductile-to-brittle transition in sintered materials. 3D printing will be used to independently vary important geometric features during sintering experiments such as the size of the starter crack, the specimen thickness, and the initial length of the uncracked ligament. By coupling experiments on these 3D printed specimens with discrete element method simulations of sinter-cracking, continuum descriptions of stresses and strains will be linked with particle-scale phenomena occurring at the crack tip to develop a multi-scale, physics-based understanding of sinter-cracking and the causes of the ductile-brittle transition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This proposal was motivated by a study in which we used high-temperature imaging to observe sinter-cracking in situ and discovered an abrupt transition in fracture behavior as we increased the sintering temperature. At low temperatures, the powder aggregate underwent slow tearing, but as we increased the sintering temperature we encountered a ductile-brittle transition beyond which the sinter-cracks grew rapidly and catastrophically. The goal of this proposal was thus to determine why this ductile-brittle transition occurs, with a view toward identifying processing strategies for suppressing fast fracture during constrained sintering.

Intellectual merits: The main impacts of this project on the principal discipline of powder processing include:

1.  Development of a novel method for in situ observation of cracking caused by the self-stress induced in materials sintering under restraint. This method was used to directly observe and quantify sinter-cracking in binder jet 3D printed specimens. The insights from this work show how both design geometry and build orientation contribute to mitigation of sinter-cracking. For example, the crack arrester configuration, in which build layers lie normal to the flaw, was found to give the greatest toughness, experiencing a longer time to sinter-crack initiation and a subsequently slower sinter-crack growth rate.

2. Development of quantitative metrics for describing and predicting the rate of sinter-cracking in powder aggregates. Specifically, we used discrete element method simulations to establish that the net section stress in a notched body correlates with the sinter-crack growth rate, demonstrating its potential to quantitatively describe sinter-cracking. We also observed greater crack growth rates in specimens of lower initial relative density, due to their lower effective viscosity. Lower effective viscosity allows greater crack tip velocity, as observed in previous sinter-cracking experiments. Thus, to suppress sinter-cracking in a powder aggregate, a greater green density is desirable.

3. Development of physics-based models that predict the effects of reactive binders on the microstructure and sintering mechanics of binder jet 3D printed ceramics. These models showed that the dominant effect of a reactive binder on the sintering mechanics is to increase the interparticle contact size, while the coordination number remains essentially unchanged. These insights were used to develop generalized guidelines for designing reactive binders to mitigate creep, quantitatively highlighting the benefits of a high solid yield from binder decomposition.

Considered together these insights suggest approaches for improving the yield and quality of binder jet 3D printed ceramics, with important potential implications for a wide range of disciplines and technologies.

Broader impacts: This work has been disseminated through several journal articles, conference papers, and technical seminars, including some given to industrial end users of binder jet 3D printing (e.g., Kennametal, GE Additive). Additionally, and perhaps more importantly, this proposal supported the PhD theses of two graduate students, Dr. Lynnora Grant and Dr. Reid Carazzone, and research internships for 6 undergraduates, all of whom successfully graduated and are now in the STEM workforce.

 


Last Modified: 01/02/2023
Modified by: Zachary C Cordero
